detailedSummary: Version control tracks changes to files over time, allowing you to revert to previous versions and collaborate effectively. Git is the most popular version control system. A repository (repo) stores project files and their history. Basic Git workflow involves: git init (initialize repository), git add (stage changes), git commit (save changes with a message), and git status (check repository state). git log shows commit history. Branches allow parallel development - the main branch is typically the production code. git branch creates branches, git checkout switches branches, and git merge combines branches. Remote repositories (like GitHub) store code online for backup and collaboration. git remote connects to remote repos, git push uploads changes, and git pull downloads changes. .gitignore excludes files from version control. Understanding Git is essential for professional web development, enabling collaboration, backup, and organized project management.
whyItMatters: Version control with Git is essential for professional development - it enables collaboration, tracks changes, allows experimentation without risk, and is required in all modern development workflows.

assignments.title: Git Workflow Practice
assignments.description: Set up a Git repository and practice basic version control workflows.
tasks: Initialize a Git repository in a project folder
Make changes to files and commit them with descriptive messages
Create a branch, make changes, and merge it back to main
Set up a GitHub account and push your repository online
Create a .gitignore file and explain what files should not be version controlled

quizzes.question: What is the purpose of 'git commit'?
options: To save staged changes with a message
quizzes.explanation: git commit saves staged changes to the repository with a descriptive message, creating a snapshot of the project at that point.

quizzes.question: Git branches allow you to work on different features simultaneously without affecting the main code.
quizzes.explanation: True. Branches create separate lines of development, allowing you to work on features independently and merge them when ready.

quizzes.question: What does 'git push' do?
options: Uploads local commits to remote repository
quizzes.explanation: git push uploads your local commits to a remote repository (like GitHub), making your changes available to others.
